facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 75 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 75 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated October 19, 1959, of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 152 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 19, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 152 of 1959. C.

facts.text: Respondent is a partnership firm in possession as tenant of shop No. 582/638 at Mulji Jetha Market, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent before us is a partnership firm. It was in possession as a tenant of a shop No. 582/638, at Mulji Jetha Market,

facts.text: Respondent instituted suit in Bombay City Civil Court for declaration of lawful possession, injunction, and commission under agreement dated June 23, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It instituted a suit in the Bombay City Civil Court  to be distinguished from the Court of Small Causes, Bombay  in which it asked for  1  a declaration that it was in lawful possession of shop No. 582/638 at Mulji Jetha Market, Bombay and that the present appellants  who were the defendants in the suit  or their family members, servants or agents had no right to enter into or remain in possession of the said shop  2  for an injunction...

facts.text: Agreement dated June 23, 1955, by which defendant No. 1 appointed respondent as commission agent for sale of appellants' cloth in the shop, for four years expiring June 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The main averments in the plaint were that by the aforesaid agreement defendant No. 1, appellant No. 1 before us, appointed the respondent as his commission agent for the sale of the appellants cloth in the shop in question. The agreement was to remain in force for a period of four years expiring on June 30, 1959.

facts.text: Pursuant to agreement, appellants allowed to visit shop only for business purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the agreement, the appellants, their family members, servants and agents were allowed by the respondent to visit the shop only for the purpose of looking after the business of commission agency.

facts.text: After expiry of agreement on June 30, 1959, appellants had no further right to enter shop.

anchor.surface_text: On the expiry of the agreement the appellants had no further right to enter into the shop and in paragraphs 10 and 11 of the plaint the respondent-firm -alleged that some commission was due to it...

facts.text: Appellants visiting shop daily after expiry, preventing respondent's access to stock, books, etc.

anchor.surface_text: but the appellants, their servants and agents were visiting the shop daily and preventing the respondent from having access to its various articles such as stock-in-trade, books of account, furniture, fixtures etc.

facts.text: Plaint alleges appellants were licensees during agreement period and trespassers after expiry; denies landlord-tenant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint proceeded on the footing that during the period of the agreement the appellants were mere licensees, and after the expiry of the agreement they were trespassers and had no right to be in the shop. The plaint in terms negatives any relationship of landlord and tenant...

facts.text: Appellants' defense: respondent sublet shop to appellants at monthly rent of Rs. 500, but created sham agreement dated June 30, 1952 to avoid penal provisions; 1955 agreement not operative; true relation landlord-tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial defence of the appellants was that the respondent-firm had sublet the shop to the appellants at a monthly rent of Rs. 500/ but as no sub-tenancy could be legally created at the time, without the consent of the landlord, by reason of the provisions of the Act, the respondent-firm with a view to safeguard its position in regard to the penal provisions of the Act required the appellants to enter into a sham agreement in the shape of a letter dated June 30, 1952. The agreement was never acted upon and was intended to be a cloak to conceal the true nature of the transaction. The appellants further alleged that the agreement dated June 23, 1955, was also not operative between the parties, and the true relation between the parties was that of landlord and tenant.

facts.text: Appellants pleaded Court of Small Causes, Bombay has exclusive jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On these averments in the written statement the appellants took the plea that as the question involved in the suit related to the possession of premises as between a landlord and his tenant, the Court of Small Causes, Bombay, alone had jurisdiction to try the suit.

facts.text: City Civil Court framed preliminary issue on jurisdiction and decided in favor of appellants, relying on Babulal Bhuramal v. Nandram Shivram (1959 SCR 367), returned plaint.

anchor.surface_text: On these pleadings a preliminary issue as to jurisdiction was framed by the City Civil Court, Bombay and this issue was in these terms Whether this court has jurisdiction to entertain and try this suit ? The learned judge of the City Civil Court relying on a decision of this court in Babulal Bhuramal v. Nandram Shivram  1 , decided the preliminary issue in favour of the present appellants...

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 152 of 1959 on October 19, 1959 reversed City Civil Court, held City Civil Court has jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken by the present respondent to the High Court of Bombay from the decision of the learned City Civil judge. The High Court pointed out in its judgment dated October 19, 1959...

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave and heard appeal on April 22, 1963.
Supreme Court held City Civil Court has jurisdiction, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we hold that the City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit and the High Court correctly came to that conclusion. Therefore, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Bombay Act LVII of 1947) enacted to control rents, repairs, evictions.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 was enacted, to amend and consolidate the law relating to the control of rents and repairs of certain premises, of. rates of hotels and lodging houses and of evictions,...

facts.text: Section 28 gives exclusive jurisdiction to Court of Small Causes, Bombay for suits between landlord and tenant re rent/possession, claims under Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 which we shall presently read deals with jurisdiction of courts s. 29 deals with appeals, and s. 29-A is a section which saves suits involving title. The particular section the interpretation of which is in question before us is s. 28...

facts.text: Sarkar J. notes suit by licensor against licensee for termination of licence.

anchor.surface_text: The suit, therefore, was by a licenser against a licensee for certain reliefs based on the termination of the licence.

facts.text: Appellants contended sub-letting to avoid ejectment by respondent's landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellants to this suit was that the relationship between the parties was not that of licenser and licensee but that the shop had in fact been sub-let to the first appellant...

facts.text: City Civil Court initially held no jurisdiction under s.28, returned plaint as preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: The City Civil Court, Bombay held that in view of s. 28 of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging Rates Control Act, 1947 it had no jurisdiction...

facts.text: High Court held s.28 does not oust jurisdiction based on defense plea.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court said that the decision in Babulal Bhuramal  1 , did not in effect hold, nor did it justify any interpretation to the effect, that s. 28 of the Act made a departure from the general principle that governs the question of jurisdiction...

facts.text: No rent claimed in suit.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously the respondents suit is not a suit for rent for no rent is claimed at all.

facts.text: Plaint does not allege landlord-tenant relation or claim possession recovery.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the plaint that the respondent filed does not show that the suit filed by it is between landlord and tenant nor does it contain any claim for recovery of possession of premises.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by K. Das J., separate by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of S.K. Das and Hidayatullah, JJ. was delivered by Das J Sarkar J., delivered separate, judgment. K. DAS J.-

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 19, 1959, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 152 of 1959. C. Chatterjee, J.B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants. V.

s. 28 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947  Bombay Act LVII of 1947  the Court of Small Causes Bombay had exclusive jurisdiction to deal with the suit out of which this appeal has arisen. The respondent before us is a partnership firm.

concepts.interpretation: Gives exclusive jurisdiction to Court of Small Causes, Bombay to entertain suits/proceedings between landlord and tenant for recovery of rent/possession of premises under Part II, applications under Act, claims/questions arising out of Act; jurisdiction determined by plaint averments alleging such relationship, not ousted by defendant's denial or plea of tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: In answering this question it is perhaps necessary to refer to the general principle which admittedly governs the question of jurisdiction at the inception of suits. This general principle has been well explained in the Full Bench decision of the Allahabad High Court, Ananti v. Chhannu 1 , and has not been disputed before us. It was observed there The plaintiff chooses his forum and files his suit.

concepts.interpretation: Jurisdiction determined at inception by averments in plaint chosen by plaintiff; not ousted or changed by facts alleged in defense; if plaint facts not supporting jurisdiction of chosen court, suit dismissed or plaint returned, but not based on defense.

issues.text: The only question which arises in this appeal is, whether on a proper interpretation of s. 28 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 the Court of Small Causes Bombay had exclusive jurisdiction to deal with the suit out of which this appeal has arisen.

anchor.surface_text: The only question which arises in this appeal is, whether on a proper interpretation of s. 28 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947  Bombay Act LVII of 1947  the Court of Small Causes Bombay had exclusive jurisdiction to deal with the suit out of which this appeal has arisen.

issues.text: Does it mean that if the defendant raises a claim or question as to the existence of a relationship of landlord and tenant between him and the plaintiff, the jurisdiction of the City Civil Court is ousted even though the plaintiff pleads that there is nosuch relationship, and the only court which has exclusive jurisdiction to try the suit is the Court of Small Causes, Bombay?

anchor.surface_text: Does it mean that if the defendant raises a claim or question as to the existence of a relationship of landlord and tenant between him and the plaintiff, the jurisdiction of the City Civil Court is ousted even though the plaintiff pleads that there is nosuch relationship, and the only court which has exclusive jurisdiction to try the suit is the Court of Small Causes, Bombay ? That is the question before us.

issues.text: Whether the suit is affected by s. 28 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question is, how far the suit is affected by s. 28 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction to try the respondents suit as a whole or in part because it would thereby be dealing with a claim or question arising under the Act.
Whether the defence raises any claim or question under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: But it is said by the appellants that the defence raises such a claim or question.

issues.text: Whether a question whether a defendant is a licensee or not, is a question or claim arising out of the Act.
Whether the question whether the appellants are sub-tenants is a question or claim arising out of the Act.
Whether if the present case is of the type contemplated by s.51, the City Civil Court would have no jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit and the High Court correctly came to that conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we hold that the City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit and the High Court correctly came to that conclusion. Therefore, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction determined by plaint averments denying landlord-tenant relationship and lacking claims for rent/possession under Act; general principle governs; s.28 exclusive jurisdiction not attracted by defendant's plea.

holdings.text: s.28 gives exclusive jurisdiction to Court of Small Causes for suits/proceedings between landlord and tenant relating to recovery of rent/possession, applications under Act, claims/questions arising out of Act, but only where plaint admits or shows such relationship/claims.

anchor.surface_text: S. 28 no doubt gives exclusive jurisdiction to the Court of Small Causes to entertain and try a suit or proceeding between a landlord and a tenant relating to recovery of rent or possession of any premises to which any of the provisions of Part II apply it also gives exclusive jurisdiction to decide any application under the Act and any claim or question arising out of the Act or any of its provisions---all this notwithstanding anything contained in any other law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.28(1); operative part covers specific suits between L&T, applications, claims under Act; dependent on existing/previous L&T relationship alleged in plaint.

holdings.text: Plea of defendant does not determine or change forum; cannot force plaintiff to forum based on denial of plaint averments.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the section says or intends to say that the plea of the defendant will determine or change the forum. It proceeds on the basis that exclusive jurisdiction is conferred on certain courts to decide all questions or claims under the Act as to parties between whom there is or was a relationship of landlord and tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle of jurisdiction at inception by plaint (Ananti v. Chhannu); defendant's plea would lead to anomalous results like multiple plaint returns.

holdings.text: Babulal Bhuramal does not assist appellants; correctly understood by Bombay High Court in Jaswantlal; s.28 covers suits framed as between L&T with reliefs under Act.

anchor.surface_text: As to the decision of this Court in Babulal Bhuramal 1 , we do not think that it assists the appellants. We consider that the Bombay High Court correctly understood it in - Jaswantlal v. Western Company, India 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Babulal, suit sought protection under Act as tenant/sub-tenant after Small Causes decree; s.28 barred second suit; observations require suit substance framed as L&T claim under Act.

holdings.text: Suit not between landlord-tenant for rent/possession; no rent claimed; plaint denies L&T, frames as licensor-licensee post-termination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Frame of suit by plaint determines; first category of s.28 requires L&T allegation and rent/possession recovery claim, absent here.

holdings.text: No claim or question arising out of Act; even defense plea of sub-tenancy does not raise such, as licensee/tenant distinction collateral, not created/regulated by Act for jurisdiction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act regulates existing tenancies, does not create them; question of contractual tenancy existence precedes Act application; no need to decide tenant rights under Act for suit.

holdings.text: s.29A negates exclusive Small Causes jurisdiction over title questions.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this contention can be accepted as correct, for to do so would be to hold that the Court of Small Causes has exclusive jurisdiction to decide question of title, which is clearly negatived by s. 29-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative argument rejected; s.29A saves title suits de hors Act.

holdings.text: Govindram Salamatrai correctly states law on jurisdiction by plaint in licensee suits.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with a similar argument in Govindram Salamatrai 1 Chagla, C.J. said There can be no doubt that when a plaintiff files a suit against a defendant alleging that he is his licensee,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Chagla CJ: licensee suit not under s.28; jurisdiction at inception by plaint; tenant plea does not oust.

holdings.text: If proceedings under Ch.VII Presidency Small Causes Act (licensee recovery), s.51 may give Small Causes exclusive jurisdiction, but not decided here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; no argument advanced, facts not on record.

anchor.surface_text: Babulal Bhuramal v. Nandram Shivram  1 , decided the preliminary issue in favour of the present appellants. Dharampal  2 , which had taken a different view was of numberassistance to the present respondent, and must be deemed to have been over-ruled by the Supreme Court decision.

precedents.citation: Ananti v. Chhannu  1   1929  I. L R. 52 All, 501

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we hold that the City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit and the High Court correctly came to that conclusion. Therefore, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: S. 28 no doubt gives exclusive jurisdiction to the Court of Small Causes to entertain and try a suit or proceeding between a landlord and a tenant relating to recovery of rent or possession of any premises to which any of the provisions of Part II apply it also gives exclusive jurisdiction to decide any application under the Act and any claim or question arising out of the Act or any of its provisions---all this notwithstanding anything contained in any other law.
Therefore, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the section says or intends to say that the plea of the defendant will determine or change the forum. It proceeds on the basis that exclusive jurisdiction is conferred on certain courts to decide all questions or claims under the Act as to parties between whom there is or was a relationship of landlord and tenant.
Therefore, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
